msContents.summary: The Pañcarakṣā corpus ("Five Protections") consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. This ancient composite palm-leaf manuscript has been dated to the 13th century by Bendall (1883: 157), although the colophon in the third codicological unit bears the date of 518 Nepāla Saṃvat, i.e 1398 CE. The colophon mentions also the reign of king Jayasthitimalla , who however reigned between 1382 and 1395. According to Bendall (1883: 157), [t]he colophon records that the MS. was the offering of one Lalitakramā. However, Lalitakramā is not the name of a person, but one of the ancient names of modern-day Patan (see for instance Petech 1984: 185), and the colophon merely mentions the place in which the manuscript was given as a gift of charity (deyadharmo 'yam pravaramahāyāyinaḥ śrīsrīlalitakramāyāṃ śrīśrīmāṇīśamāttaramahāvihāre). Many folios of the manuscript are later supplies in paper. At the beginning of each dhāraṇī, a space was left blank for a miniature that, however, was never painted. The last page of the manuscript has been "written on the back of a leaf (of an avadāna?), which is in the same hand (viz., that of the xiiith cent.) as the bulk of the MS., but is not divided into columns, as that is (Bendall 1883: 157)". Actually, the verso of this folio contains a part of the Mahāpratisarā.

physDesc.p: Composite manuscript consisting of three codicological units. The second and third codicological units are dependent units; the second unit consists of paper supplies for folios 14-16, 18-19, 22-24, 41, 45, 56, 60-61, 65, 78, 81, 107-109, 111-112, 130, 131-132, and of the original paper restorations of the kernel; the third unit is simply the last palm-leaf folio.

supportDesc.support:
Palm-leaf and paper.
All codicological units have the same size.
5.3 33.3

bindingDesc.p: Wood cover: one original cover, but not belonging to this manuscript, as it is only 4cm high and bears only one string hole; one library cover.

history.origin:
13th-14th century (see the date for each codicological unit; the second unit consists of modern paper replacements).
Nepāl, Pātan.
history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright on behalf of the Cambridge University Library in 1876.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).

supportDesc.condition: Incomplete, in passable condition. The text is very often faded or smudged, and quite often retraced. Many original paper restorations of worn-out edges, with the missing part of the text written in Nepālākṣara; these restorations most probably belong to the second codicological unit.

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 52 akṣaras per line.

The layout of the page is normally divided into three pseudocolumns. Each pseudocolumn is delimited by double frame lines on both sides; each of the two different foliations are further delimited by double lines, respectively on the left side (for the letter-numerals on the mid-left margin) and right side (for the numerals on the mid-right margin). Although most probably belonging to this codicological unit, folio 46 and folio 97 have a different layout, with two string holes approximately in the middle of a square blank space (height 2cm, width 2-2.5cm). Some elaborate puṣpikās.
layout.stringHole:
Two string holes approximately in the middle of a blank column-like space.
2.5

handNote.desc: First hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) in black ink (main text); quite a few passages have been retraced, probably by the same hand that wrote the second codicological unit (see for instance the transition from f. 19v5 to f. 20r1, samya va [for samyag eva] paripāci[20r1]tāni bhaviṣyanti ativṛṣṭyānāvṛṣṭidoṣāḥ, where on f. 21 r the first words tāni bhaviṣyanti ativṛṣṭyā have been retraced (and tāni bha even added on the margin).
Second hand: Nepālākṣarā in black ink (marginal corrections).

list.item: On 33r, an invocation in Nepālākṣarā script : [l1] $ oṃ āḥ huṃ || śubham astu || [l2] $ jīrṇṇodhāraka aśanyācāryyaśrībṛhaspatiṃ jaro || śubham astu || @

item.marginalia: Rare marginal corrections (and possibly annotations) throughout the manuscript.

origin.origDate: 13th century (Bendall 1883: 157); 518 Nepāla / 1398 CE (according to the colophon in the third codicological unit).

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 48 akṣaras per line.
The layout of the page is divided into three pseudocolumns, each delimited by Two pairs of double frame lines.
layout.stringHole:
Two string holes approximately in the middle of a blank column-like space.
2.5

supportDesc.condition: The text is faded and sometimes retraced.

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 57 akṣaras per line.
The layout of the page is divided into three pseudocolumns, each pseudocolumn is delimited by double frame lines on both sides.
layout.stringHole:
Two string holes approximately in the middle of a blank column-like space.
2

handNote.desc: First hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) in black ink.
Second hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) in black ink (deleted text on the verso).

physDesc.additions: This folio originally belonged to another manuscript of the Pañcarakṣā, since on the verso (numbered 19 with a foliation in Nepālākṣarā numerals on the mid-right margin) a part of the Mahāpratisarā is found (as it stands in the manuscript, from °khaṇḍako dattādāyī sukhādvārahārikaḥ saṃghikaṃ cāturdiśikaṃ gaṇaprāptañ ca yad dravyan tat paudgalikaṃ kṛtvā sarvam adhiṣṭhāya takṣayati to tasyā eva rātryāḥ atyayātra svapasthitaḥ smṛtiḥ kālagataḥ | sat asmin kadravare utsṛṣṭa avīcau ma-8- ).

origin.origDate: probably 1382-1395, during the reign of Jayasthitimalla (see the colophon in this codicological unit).
